origin_of_ch_char_book: The first born son had a privilege as the inheritor of the parents’ family fortune. In return, the oldest son was responsible for the ceremonies of ancestors and parents. With such privilege, the eldest son had power over his younger siblings. Therefore, the eldest son often ordered his younger siblings around. (兄, xiong=hsiung, elder brother) describes elder brother, which combines a (口, kou, mouse) and a person (人, ren, human). Together, they symbolize “a person who speaks or gives orders”. If the spirit tablet or altar (示, shi=shih, show) is added to the left , (祝, zhu, wish), it means the eldest brother who represents the group praying or calling a blessing from God. Then, how can the younger brother be depicted? The creator(s) of Hanzi thought about the sequence of brothers. The character (弟, di, younger brother) shows a spear in the middle (戈), and a rope winding the spear (). The reason for winding the spear is to prevent slippage and to make sure the spear will not break. This character came to mean “younger brother” because of the meaning of winding order, or sequence. When you wind a rope around the spear, you have to do it in an orderly way. Therefore, it symbolizes the order in the ages of the siblings.
humanum_full_description_en:
Jia Jinwen starts from " mouth " from " person ", it means that people can open their mouths to speak. In ancient times, the elder brother was the person who gave orders and had the responsibility of supervising the brothers (Shen Pei), so the word " brother " followed "口" is a sign. The original meaning is brother. "Said Wen": "Brother, Chang Ye. From the child to the mouth. All brothers belong to the brother."

In Jiajin inscriptions, the shape of fingers may be drawn in the shape of " person " from " brother ", which is similar to the shape of " long ", " old ", " kao ", etc., which are often written over the hand, to indicate that the elder brother is older People: It is said that the " brother " in the form of covering the hand may be the initial ideogram of the " bun " that expresses the reward. Because there are many kinds of rewards, it is not drawn, and only the hand shape is emphasized to indicate the action of award. Shen Pei believes that the " brother " in the form of a hand-covered hand is not only a variant of the elder brother's " brother ", but also an initial ideogram of " Ben ".

Later, the " mouth "-shaped horizontal pen runs through the left and right vertical pens, which are similar to the " twenty " shape. Or add " 𡉚 " (" to ") as the sound note . Or add the meaning of " person ".

In addition, pay attention to the distinction between the ancient characters "祝" and " brother ". The difference between the character " brother " and the character "祝" which does not follow the " show " is that the figure of " brother " is standing, while the figure of "祝" in the early days is kneeling (Yao Xiaosui).

The oracle bone inscription is used as the original meaning to indicate that the elder brother is the object of sacrifice. "Compilation" 2870: "㞢(yor) elder brother Jia", which means yor sacrifice to the elder brother. Bronze inscriptions are also used as the original meaning to mean elder brother, Wang Sun's survivor Zhong: "Guest father and brother with music" means to entertain guests and father and elder brother. Qi Houpin: "Brother Baowu". It is also used as "贶", which means a reward, to make a booklet. Yi: "Ling Zha (zuo) Chuzhe's brother (贶) Wang Tu Yuxianghou". "Zuoshu" is the official name, which refers to the booklet and is responsible for the documents The historian of records. " Zhe " is the name of a person, and "Wang Tu" is the land of Wang Di, which means that a booklet is ordered to give Wang Di to the lords. The Chinese tripod: "Brother Jin (贶) 畀you 䙐土, make a nai Cai." "贶畀" is synonymous with the word "giving", which means that the land given to you now is your favorite. "Er Ya. "Explanation": "Ben, thanks."

The difference between " Ben " and " Give " is that " Ben " refers to the transfer of rewards, and " Give " refers to the gift from the top to the bottom, and no one transfers it (Peng Yushang).

The bamboo slips of the Warring States Period are also used as the original meaning, referring to the older brother, "Shangbo Bamboo Book IV. "Neifeng" Jane 4: "In ancient times, those who are brothers and speakers cannot be merciful (brother), and those who are not the same as the elder brothers cannot be acquainted (brother) "It means that if you are a elder brother, you should talk about your brother’s inability to be kind to your brother, and don’t talk about your brother’s failure to accept your brother (Ji Xusheng).
humanum_short_description_en: The meaning of the people of the Jiajingwenhui who speak openly. In ancient times, the elder brother was the commander and had the responsibility of supervising the younger brothers, so he used the " mouth ". The original meaning is brother.
humanum_full_description:
甲金文從「口」從「人」，會人張開口說話之意，古時兄長是發施號令的人，有督率諸弟的責任(沈培)，故「兄」字從「口」為意符。本義是兄長。《說文》：「兄，長也。从儿从口。凡兄之屬皆从兄。」

　　甲金文或於「兄」字所從的「人」形畫出手指之形，與「長」、「老」、「考」等字常寫作覆手形相近，以表示兄長是年紀比較大的人；一說從覆手形的「兄」可能是表示賞賜的「貺」的表意初文，因為賞賜物多種多樣，所以沒有畫出來，只強調手形，以表示授予的動作。沈培認為從覆手形的「兄」既是兄長的「兄」的異體，也是「貺」的表意初文。

　　後期文字「口」形的橫筆貫穿左右的豎筆，與「廿」形近。或加從「𡉚」(「往」)為聲符。或加從「人」為意符。

　　此外，注意區別古文字「祝」和「兄」。「兄」字和不從「示」的「祝」字的分別是「兄」的人形是站立的，而早期「祝」字的人形是跪坐的(姚孝遂)。

　　甲骨文用作本義，表示兄長，是祭祀對象，《合集》2870：「㞢(侑)兄甲」，表示對兄甲進行侑祭。金文也用作本義，表示兄長，王孫遺者鐘：「用樂嘉賓父兄」，表示以娛樂賓客和父親、兄長。齊侯鎛：「保吾兄弟」。又用作「貺」，表示賞賜，作冊折方彝：「令乍(作)冊折兄(貺)望土于相侯」，「作冊」是官名，指掌管簡冊，負責文書記錄的史官。「折」是人名，「望土」是望地的田土，表示命令作冊折賞賜望土給相侯。中方鼎：「今兄(貺)畀汝䙐土，作乃采。」「貺畀」同義連文，表示賜予，意謂如今賞賜給你䙐地的田土，作為你的采邑。《爾雅．釋詁》：「貺，賜也。」

　　「貺」與「賜」的分別是，「貺」指轉交賞賜物，而「賜」則是指上對下的賜與，中間無他人轉交(彭裕商)。

　　戰國竹簡也用作本義，指兄長，《上博竹書四．內豊》簡4：「古(故)為人兄者言人之㑆(兄)之不能慈俤(弟)，不與言人之俤(弟)之不能氶(承)㑆(兄)者。」意謂因此做人兄長的，應談論哥哥不能慈愛弟弟的情況，不去談論弟弟不承奉哥哥的情況(季旭昇)。
